title: Elections: Maldives President 2023
text:
IFES Election Guide | Elections: Maldives President 2023

Home

Countries

Maldives
›
Maldivian Presidency 2023-General
Sept. 9, 2023
Held
Republic of Maldives
Election for Maldivian Presidency
Results
Voter Participation
Voter Turnout*
Cast Votes:225,846
Valid Votes:220,651
Invalid Votes:4,835
Registered Voters:282,395
Mohamed MUIZ101,635
46.06
Ibrahim Mohamed SOLIH86,161
39.05
Ilyas LABEEB15,839
7.18
Election Results Modified: Nov 06, 2023
General Information
At Stake in this Election:
The Presidency of the Maldives
Government Structure:
Chief of State: President Ibrahim Mohamed SOLIH (since 17 November 2018)
Head of Government: President Ibrahim Mohamed SOLIH (since 17 November 2018)
Assembly: unicameral People’s Assembly (ރައްޔިތުންގެ މަޖިލިސް) with 87 seats
Electoral System:
The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and serves up to two 5-year terms.
In the People’s Assembly, 87 members are directly elected by plurality vote in single-seat constituencies. Members serve 5-year terms.
Last Election:
In 2018, Ibrahim Mohamed SOLIH (MDP) won the presidency in a single round, earning 58.82% of the vote and defeating Abdulla YAMEEN (PPM). Voter turnout was 89%.
Key Deadlines:
Candidate filing deadline: 3 August 2023
Voter registration deadline: N/A; voter registration is passive.
Voters can request changes to their registered polling location until 5 August 2023.
Main Candidates in this Election:
Ibrahim Mohamed SOLIH
Maldivian Democratic Party/ ދިވެހިރައްޔިތުންގެ ޑިމޮކްރެޓިކް ޕާޓީ (MDP)
Incumbent
Ilyas LABEEB
The Democrats / ދަ ޑިމޮކްރެޓްސް
Mohamed MUIZ
People’s National Congress / ޕީޕަލްސް ނޭޝަނަލް ކޮންގްރެސް (PNC)
Mohamed NAZIM
Maldives National Party / މޯލްޑިވްސް ނެޝަނަލް ޕާޓީ އެމް. (MNP)
Umar NASEER
Independent
Hassan ZAMEEL
Independent
Faris MAUMOON
Independent
Population and Registered Voters:
Population: 389,568 (2023 est.)
Registered Voters: 264,442 (2019)
Female Population: 189,111 (2023 est.)
CEDAW Status: Ratified (by accession) 1 July 1993
Gender Quota:  No
Female Candidates in this election: No
Number of Female Legislators (pre-election): 4 out of 87 (4.6%) in the People’s Assembly
Human Development Index (HDI) Position: 0.747, High, Rank 90 (2021)
Social Institutions and Gender Index (SIGI) Categorization: Not available
Disability Data:
CRPD Status: Signed 2 October 2007, Ratified 5 April 2010
Projected population with a disability: 58435 (2023 est.)
IFES Resources:
Does IFES have a presence in the Maldives: No
Election Access: Yes
Election Judgements: Yes, 1 judgment and 3 resources
Election Modified: Sep 11, 2023

01 Oct 2023
Transparency Maldives says runoff presidential poll peaceful
Posted by ANFREL
With 0 Comment
In Maldives, Network News
Maldives headed to a runoff election on 30 September 2023 after no presidential candidate was able to secure enough votes to win. Transparency Maldives (TM) said the election was relatively peaceful with a few isolated cases of reported violence at polling stations. TM observed a few number of voters weren't able to
Read More
11 Sep 2023
Transparency Maldives’ Interim Report on the 2023 Presidential Election
Posted by ANFREL
With 0 Comment
In Maldives, Network News
Transparency Maldives, in their interim statement on the 2023 Presidential Election, said the Election day processes went well but expressed some concerns about the election environment especially on abuse of state resources. Election Day The report indicated that the Election Day administration was well managed by the Elections Commission (EC). The opening
Read More
11 Sep 2023
Transparency Maldives’ statement on the opening and closing of polls during 2023 Presidential Election
Posted by ANFREL
With 0 Comment
In Maldives, Network News
Transparency Maldives said in their initial observation statements that the 2023 Maldivian Presidential Election was generally peaceful and orderly. The opening procedure at polling stations went well with all polling stations open by 9 a.m. and 85% of polling stations open within the first 10 minutes of the required opening time. The
Read More
19 Jun 2023
Press Statement: Transparency Maldives Pre-election interim assessment findings of the 2023 presidential election
Posted by ANFREL
With 0 Comment
In Maldives, Network News
Transparency Maldives released their findings of the pre-election interim assessment of the 2023 presidential election. The election is scheduled for 9 September 2023. Transparency Maldives (TM) is a non-partisan, non-governmental and non-profit organization. It has been the main domestic Elections Observer Group since 2008. Prior to fielding its nation-wide observation, TM conducts
Read More
15 Mar 2023
Joint Press Statement: Transparency Maldives and Maldives Journalists Association express concern regarding the proposed amendments to the Election (General) Act 11/2008
Posted by ANFREL
With 0 Comment
In Maldives, Network News
We are greatly concerned by the government's proposed amendments to the Election (General) Act 11/2008 that will potentially restrict the scope of journalists monitoring elections, just six months ahead of this year's presidential elections. According to the proposed amendment to Section 41 of the Act, only registered journalists will be allowed to
Read More
09 Jan 2023
Stop abuse of state resources, uphold election integrity – Transparency Maldives to State
Posted by ANFREL
With 0 Comment
In Maldives, Network News
Transparency Maldives calls on the State to stop the abuse of State resources and uphold the integrity of election and ensure a free and fair electoral process. The abuse of State resources can be a corruptive force in the electoral process, as it introduces or exacerbates power inequalities and gives unfair advantage
Read More

PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION 2023 - ANNOUNCEMENT FOR INTERNATIONAL OBSERVERS AND MONITORS TO OBSERVE/MONITOR THE ELECTORAL PROCESS OF THE SECOND ROUND OF PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION OF THE MALDIVES
14 ÞÞ¬ÞÞ°ÞÞ¬ÞÞ°ÞÞ¦ÞÞª 2023, 12:00
ÞÞ¨ÞÞªÞÞ§ÞÞ°
No:(IUL)38-FA/38/2023/409,Date: September 14th, 2023
PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION 2023
ANNOUNCEMENT FOR INTERNATIONAL OBSERVERS AND MONITORS TO OBSERVE/MONITOR THEELECTORAL PROCESS OF THE SECOND ROUND OF PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION OF THE MALDIVES
The second round of the 2023 presidential Elections of Maldives is Scheduled to be held on the 30th of September 2023. In line with the Second round of the 2023 Presidential Elections of Maldives, the Commission has decided to extend the accreditations issued to the International Observers and Monitors during the First round of elections.
Additionally, applications are open for interested parties from the below-mentioned institutions/organizations to observe and monitor the electoral process of the second round.
Applications will be accepted until the 17thof September 2023.
THE CRITERIA FOR INTERNATIONAL OBSERVERS AND MONITORS ARE AS FOLLOWS
Should be 18 years of age.
Representatives of International Associations and Societies related to electoral activities accredited by the Associations they belong to.
Applicants should not be involved in campaigning for any candidate or political party to win support for any such activity in that manner.
International observers and monitors for the Presidential Election should act in accordance with Section 40 and 41 respectively of the Constitutional Act, 11/2008 Elections (General) Act as well as adhere to the Code of Conduct as stipulated in the Regulations for Presidential Election 2023.
Details on the form need to be entered as in the applicant’s passport.
Attachments required to submit with the application form should meet the following criteria and should not exceed10MB in file size.
Color scan of passport which has at least 6 months of validity (in pdf format).
A recent passport size picture which was taken not more than three months ago. (In JPEG format, with resolution not less than 600dpi).
A signed and scanned copy of ‘Presidential Election, Observer/ Monitor Declaration’.
A letter of accreditation from the institution he/she is representing. This letter should include the applicant’s full name, passport number and designation. The letter should be on the official letterhead of the representing institution and should bear the official stamp as well.
All the documents are to be submitted via email to.
The application form is to be rejected if the form is incomplete, incorrect, the declaration is unsigned, or any attachment mentioned in this announcement is missing or unattached.
Upon the accreditation, the Commission will provide an accreditation letter and handover observer/monitor passes respectively.
KEY NOTES
All the expenses, visas, and insurance from arrival to departure from the Maldives are to be borne by the observer/monitor himself/herself or by the institution he/she is representing.
The Commission will only arrange brief sessions for the accreditation of both international observers and monitors.Upon the accreditation, the Commission will provide observer/monitor passes respectively.
Observers and monitors who wish to travel across the country are to organize all the logistics and other arrangements by themselves.
Observers and monitors who wish to meet other stakeholders and political parties are to organize all the meetings, logistical arrangements, and other activities by themselves in accordance with the Acts, Regulations, and adhere to the Code of Conduct mentioned.
Application form, Declaration, and Code of Conduct are attached with the announcement and are available from our website.
14 September 2023
APPLICATION FORM
CODE OF CONDUCT
DECLARATION

Maldives
Maldivian presidential election heads for a crucial runoff
Former President Mohamed Nasheed emerges as kingmaker after first-round surprises. Published : Sep 10, 2023 09:30 IST - 4 MINS READ R.K. Radhakrishnan
COMMents
Follow Us
SHARE
Copy link
Email
Facebook
Twitter
Telegram
LinkedIn
WhatsApp
Reddit
READ LATER
SEE ALL
Remove
An electoral worker shows a ballot paper during counting the for Maldives’ presidential election in Male on September 9, 2023.
| Photo Credit: MOHAMED AFRAH
The Maldivian presidential election headed for a run off on September 30 after no candidate managed to receive the 50 per cent plus vote to win in the first round held on September 9. Former President and current People’s Majlis (parliament) Speaker Mohamed Nasheed, who parted ways with the ruling party, the Maldives Democratic Party (MDP), and floated his own party, The Democrats, has emerged as a key figure ahead of the run-off. His support could prove crucial in determining the outcome.Both the Maldivian President Ibrahim Mohamed Solih and the main opposition Progressive Party of Maldives candidate Mohamed Muizzu, were confident of winning in the first round and said as much during their campaigns. However, the voters had different plans.At the end of the vote count, with a total of 2,25,486 votes polled, Muizzu secured the first position with 1,01,635 votes (46.06 per cent), while President “Ibu” Solih, despite the largesse he gave the people in the last few months in power, managed only 86,161 votes (39.05 per cent). In third place was Mohamed Nasheed’s proxy candidate, Ilyas Labeeb, with 15,839 votes (7.18 per cent), according to the Elections Commission. The Maldives has a total of 2,82,395 eligible voters spread across 188 islands within the country and in five countries abroad.Also Read | Maldives presidential election 2023: Debt, India’s military presence major concernsIn the second round, only the candidates placed first and second will compete. This sets the stage for political negotiations across the spectrum. Nasheed’s new party, The Democrats, finished third in the first round, compelling both Ibu Solih’s party, the MDP, and the PPM to seek his support. The other candidates in the race failed to make a significant impact in the first round. In fact, the closest contender to The Democrats was an independent candidate, Umar Naseer, who garnered less than half the votes secured by The Democrats, with 6,343 votes (2.87 per cent).Another familiar face in the contest, Jumhooree Party’s Qasim Ibrahim, lagged behind independent candidate Umar Naseer, indicating a decline in his popularity compared to previous elections. Qasim Ibrahim secured only 5,460 votes (2.47 per cent). The Maldivian National Party’s Mohamed Nazim, who claimed during the campaigns that he was the one responsible for expelling India’s GMR company from the Maldives (the company had operated and managed the Male International Airport), positioning himself as the leader of the ‘Indians out of Maldives’ campaign, failed to gain much traction and received only 1,907 votes (0.86 per cent).Dunya Maumoon, one of the daughters of former President Maumoon Abdul Gayoom, is an MNP official. Her brother, Ahmed Faris Maumoon, an independent candidate, managed to secure 2,979 votes (1.35 per cent) and won this “sibling rivalry” race.
Mohamed Nasheed and Ibrahim Mohamed Solih in Male on November 1, 2018.
| Photo Credit:
MOHAMED SHARUHAAN
Nasheed’s party ran a “Not Ibu” and “Anyone but Ibu” campaign across the 188 inhabited islands in the Maldives. In an interview with Frontline, Nasheed expressed his intention to support the PPM-People’s National Congress (PNC) candidate, emphasising that his presence could help moderate the PPM-PNC’s anti-India stance.When asked about his opposition to a second term for Ibu Solih, Nasheed cited his disappointment with the MDP. He wanted a change in the form of government, and despite an agreement drawn up ahead of the 2018 elections, Ibu Solih failed to honour it. Nasheed explained that their differences emerged just before the election, and that they had previously promised to address issues related to the presidential system, transitioning to a parliamentary system, and forming an inclusive government. However, he said, subsequent events made him realise that there was no longer a place for him within the party. He stated, “They might not want to see me out. But when everyone else was not included, marginalised, then there was no reason why I should stay.”Also Read | Can Maldivian President Ibu Solih defy the odds and secure a second term?Muizzu received just over 46 per cent of the votes in the first round, while Ibu Solih managed slightly over 39 per cent. For Muizzu to secure victory, he will need to either gain the support of Nasheed (whose representative garnered just over seven per cent of the votes) or seek support from everyone remaining in the field, including Jumhooree Party’s Qasim Ibrahim, the independent Umar Naseer, and Faris Maumoon, and hope that the votes for independent candidates shift in his favour.Ibu Solih faces a tougher challenge in bridging the 10-plus percent vote gap he requires to win. If Nasheed declines to support him, it will be exceedingly difficult for him to secure enough votes from the smaller parties and independent candidates. Both remaining candidates in the runoff, as well as most political parties, will need to navigate the India-versus-China angle, and will be subjected to pressures from geopolitical actors.But for most political parties, this situation is not new: it is indeed a happy place to be.
